msContents.summary: Grant of hereditary rights of land to Rājarāja-Piccaṉ and his lineage to sing holy hymns tiruppatiyam and appoint daily reciters viṇṇappam-ceyvār. The land rights were taken from a group of blind men who were in charge of chanting the hymns.

Second year of the king Kulōttuṅka-cōḻa, emperor of the three worlds, alias the king Rājakesarivarman.

We have given as land rights mutal-kāṇi in this village which are the land rights kāṇi rights kāṇi for the recitation of holy hymns tiruppatiyam in the temple to Rājarāja Piccaṉ, alias Poyyāta-cevaṭi Tēvakaṉātaṉ, and his relatives vaṟkattār, so that they sing the holy hymns tiruppatiyam in our TēvāramNote on the meaning of this term in this context. Ask U. Veluppillai. after excluding blind people kuruṭar who utter pāṭivar the holy hymns in the temple of god Āḷuṭaiya-Aḻakiyatēvar of the tēvatāṉam Tiruvāmāttūr located in Vāvalūr-nāṭu belonging to Paṉaiyūr-nāṭu in the boundaries of Irājarāja-vaḷa-nātu.

Since it came vantaimaiyil to make the grace of a royal order, gracefully proclaiming that: Let it be written in stone that, according to the agreement nivanta-p paṭi, the rights for the land are taken from them, he and those from his lineage are appointed the hereditary rights for the singing of holy hymns tiruppatiyam, which in previous years was appointed to the blind men, thus follow:
[Measurements of rice and lands with annual and monthly quantities to the reciters are given here.]

We have given hereditary rights kāṇi to Rājarāja Piccaṉ, alias this poyyāta-cevaṭi-tēvar, and those from his lineage, so that they become the ones who appoint ceytuvar kaṭavarkaḷ daily reciters viṇṇappam ceyvār of holy hymns tiruppatiyam, according to the way in which it was done when the land was managed kaikkoṇṭu by the blind men. They formerly made the daily recitation viṇṇappam ceytu of holy hymns tiruppatiyam on the three junctions of the day santi. The eighteen great singers of these holy hymns managed kaikkoṇṭu the land nilam in accordance to how it was distributed kalanpaṭiyē in this village ūr.
